headline: Awosika seeks more women in leadership positions
summarized_story:

“Women have so much power, but they have silos power; once you have silos power, it is disconnected.

headline: Invest in your country, Gambari urges Nigerians

headline: NLC seeks FG intervention in ASUU strike
summarized_story:
Ayuba WabbaThe Nigeria Labour Congress (NLC) has called on the Federal Government to address issues that necessitated the ongoing strike by the Academic Staff Union of Universities(ASUU) and other unions in tertiary institutions.
President of NLC, Ayuba Wabba, made the call when he addressed newsmen shortly before going into a closed door meeting of the Congress’s Central Working Committee (CWC) on Wednesday in Abuja.
Recall that ASUU embarked on a nationwide warning strike to press home its members’ demands from Feb. 14.
The lecturers’ demands include; funding of the Revitalisation of Public Universities, Earned Academic Allowances, University Transparency Accountability Solution (UTAS) and promotion arrears.

headline: China confirms first human case of H3N8 bird flu
summarized_story:
China has confirmed the first human infection of the H3N8 strain of bird flu in Zhumadian within Henan province.
The National Health Commission (NHC) announced the case in a statement, adding that the risk of spread was low.
The H3N8 variant was previously detected in some countries in horses, dogs, birds and seals.
Bird flu causes aching muscles, fever, headache, cough and diarrhoea.
Others are chest pain, stomach pain, conjunctivitis, and bleeding from the nose and gums.

headline: Jigawa: Police direct investigation into alleged extra-judicial killing by NDLEA officials
summarized_story:
The Jigawa State Commissioner of Police CP Aliyu Sale Tafida has directed a thorough and clinical investigation into alleged extra-judicial killing by National Drug Law Enforcement Agency, NDLEA, officials.

DAILY POST reported that the National Drugs Law Enforcement Agency (NDLEA) personnel have allegedly killed a 25-year-old man Murtala Gambo at Sundimina Village in Birnin Kudu local Government while on patrol.

headline: Umar seeks international help for release of kidnapped Kaduna-Abuja train passengers
summarized_story:
Col. Abubakar Dangiwa Umar (rtd), former Kaduna State military administrator, has asked the Federal Government to do more to secure immediate release of the victims following the release of photographs of Abuja-Kaduna train passengers kidnapped by terrorists on the 28th March, 2022.
Col. Abubakar Dangiwa Umar also appealed to the international community to assist the federal government of Nigeria in the negotiations which will be needed with the terrorists to effect the release of the victims.
DAILY POST recall that the terrorists had on Monday night released four photographs showing 62 victims in their captivity, including 18 women, five children and 39 men, including a foreigner.
Col. Umar in a statement he issued on Wednesday described the sight of the victims in the photographs in a state of exhaustion and fear, as disturbing.
He appealed to the Federal government to do more to secure the immediate release of these innocent victims so that they would return back to their homes.

headline: Senate criminalises ransom payment to kidnappers
summarized_story:
From Fred Itua, AbujaThe Senate, yesterday, passed a bill seeking to amend the Terrorism (Prevention) Act 2013, and to prohibit the payment of ransom to kidnappers in the country.
The passage of the bill followed the consideration of a report by its Committee on Judiciary, Human Rights and Legal Matters.
In the memoranda presented to the committee, several issues relating to terrorism and terrorism financing in line with global best practices were raised.
Bamidele, in his presentation, said the bill sought to outlaw the payment of ransom to abductors, kidnappers and terrorists for release of any person who has been wrongfully confined, imprisoned or kidnapped.
He emphasised that the proposed repeal and enactment bill was geared towards improving the effectiveness of countermeasures against terrorism, terrorism financing and proliferation financing.

headline: $418m Paris Club Refund: Court grants substituted service of contempt charge against four SANs
summarized_story:
A Federal High Court in Abuja has ordered that contempt charge be served on four senior lawyers involved in the $418 million Paris Club refund suit through Courier services.
The four Senior Advocates of Nigeria (SANs) are Sunday Ibrahim Ameh, Jubrin Okutepa, Garba Tetengi and Olumuyiwa Akinboro.
The contempt charge was initiated against them by a private company, Panic Alerts and its sponsor, George Uboh, who accused the lawyers of engaging in wrongdoings in their service to their client.
The aggrieved applicants asked the court for an order to serve the contempt charge on the lawyers through a nominated courier company and by pasting same in their respective offices.
However Justice Ekwo proceeded with the ex-parte application and granted the requests of the two applicants.

headline: Zenith Sustains Position as Nigeria’s Best Bank for Three Consecutive Years in Global Finance Award
summarized_story:
Nume EkegheZenith Bank Plc has emerged as the Best Bank in Nigeria in the Global Finance Magazine’s Best Banks Awards 2022, retaining the award for a third consecutive year.
The bank was among other banks from 36 countries in Africa recognised as the prestigious Global Finance announced its 29th Annual Best Bank Awards Winners.
The editors of Global Finance made the selections after extensive consultations with corporate financial executives, bankers and banking consultants, and analysts worldwide.

headline: Elon Musk Reaches Agreement to Acquire Twitter for $44bn
summarized_story:
•Over 40 million Nigerians on microblogging platformWorld’s richest man, billionaire Elon Musk has reached an agreement to acquire Twitter for approximately $44 billion, the company said.
“Twitter has a purpose and relevance that impacts the entire world,” its CEO Parag Agrawal said in a tweet.
Musk, a prolific Twitter user, has said it needs to be taken private to grow and become a genuine platform for free speech.
Musk unveiled his intention to buy Twitter on April 14, and take it private via a financing package comprised of equity and debt.
Musk did not provide any financing details when he first disclosed his offer for Twitter, making the market skeptical about its prospects.

headline: Ogun Governor, Abiodun Confirms He Was Arrested For Fraud In USA, Warns APC Party Not To Disqualify Him For 2023
summarized_story:
Ogun State Governor, Dapo Abiodun, has said his arrest in the United States over credit card fraud and forgery in 1986 is not sufficient grounds for his disqualification by the All Progressives Congress (APC).
Governor Dapo AbiodunSofela had warned that the party might lose the governorship seat in Ogun due to Abiodun’s criminal history and its concealment from the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) despite swearing an oath.
The governor was said to have used a pseudo name (Shawn Michael Davids) with the aim of concealing his criminal identity.
The record revealed that Abiodun was jailed for committing criminal offences which bordered on credit card fraud, petty theft and check forgery.
He was arrested on November 7, 1986, for fighting and injuring a police officer in an attempt to resist arrest.

summarized_story:

He however said that he has not informed the President of his ambition because Buhari’s antecedent is not to back a presidential aspirant.
A video showing members of a security outfit in Benue state called the Nigeria Hunters and Forest Security Service assaulting a lady by forcefully shaving her hair in public is making the rounds on social media.
Finally, A Nigerian Pastor identified as Ade Abraham of Christ High Commission Ministry in Kaduna State, is making headlines after he allegedly charged members of his church N310 thousand Naira each to fly them to heaven.

headline: Victor Umeh: The Presidency Must Come to The South to keep Nigeria Together
summarized_story:
Former National Chairman of the All Progressives Grand Alliance, Senator Victor Umeh, speaks to ARISE about the call for an Igbo presidency.
In light of the zoning controversies several parties have experienced so far in the shadow of 2023 elections, Senator Umeh shares his thoughts on why the presidency should be zoned to the South East, in order to maintain and equal and fair electoral process.

headline: Major Japan Railway Now Powered Only by Renewable Energy
summarized_story:
Nicholas Little, director of railway education at Michigan State University’s Center for Railway Research and Education, commends Tokyu for promoting renewable energy but stressed the importance of boosting the bottom-line amount of that renewable energy.
“I would stress the bigger impacts come from increasing electricity generation from renewable sources,” he said.
Only about 20% of Japan’s electricity comes from renewable sources, according to the Institute for Sustainable Energy Policies, a Tokyo-based independent non-profit research organization.
That lags way behind New Zealand, for instance, where 84% of power used comes from renewable energy sources.
The country aims to have 36%-38% of its energy come from renewable sources by 2030, while slashing overall energy use.

headline: Russia Halts Gas Supplies to Poland, Bulgaria for Failing to Pay in Roubles
summarized_story:
Russian energy firm Gazprom said on Wednesday it had halted gas supplies to Bulgaria and Poland for failing to pay for gas in roubles, the Kremlin’s toughest retaliation yet to international sanctions over the war in Ukraine.
Gazprom said in a statement it had “completely suspended gas supplies to Bulgargaz and PGNiG due to absence of payments in roubles,” referring to the Polish and Bulgarian gas companies.
Poland receives its Russian gas through the Yamal-Europe pipeline from Russia’s huge gas fields in the Arctic far north, which continues west to supply Germany and other European countries.
“Cutting gas supplies is a breach of contract and PGNiG reserves the right to seek compensation and will use all available contractual and legal means to do so,” the company said.
Germany, the biggest buyer of Russian energy, said this week it is hoping to stop importing Russian oil within days.
